metadata.sermon_start_end: The church has always known that God’s Easter power for life is loose in the world. The church has always trusted in God’s capacity to bring life out of death, well-being out of trouble, and joy out of tribulation. But the church has not always known how [...] when we hunger and thirst for God’s justice, we will be filled ... filled with joy and well-being and security, a new life that has transformative power of an Easter kind.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage, instead treating three disparate lectionary texts as a thematic 'counsel' for the church. It treats the Bible as a source of 'useful and suggestive' advice rather than a unique, current Word. The preacher explicitly admits to following the lectionary rather than the internal necessity of a single text.
quotes: Since these are the lectionary readings for the day... the counsel of these texts seems to me useful and suggestive.
So here is the counsel I read in these texts.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., the Luke passage) and identify what is unique to that text that cannot be found elsewhere, rather than harmonizing three texts into general moral categories.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial. While the preacher correctly identifies the context of 2 Thessalonians (not welfare programs), the historical-critical depth is minimal. There is a brief mention of a Greek word ('I will give you mouth'), but it serves a rhetorical point rather than a deep exposition of the first readers' situation.
quotes: The early church to which Paul writes was in a very tough place...
But the Greek is, 'I will give you mouth.'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the historical and theological context of the Isaiah vision or the Lukan eschatology to move beyond 'I have a dream' parallels.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding social issues (health care, immigration, oil spills), which aligns with Dekker's requirement for relevance. However, it often slips into 'general truths' about neighborliness and 'contributing' which lack the sharp edge of the Word.
quotes: He mentions everything except the oil spill...
...implications of that new rule of God for all kinds of policy questions from health care to immigration policy.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid turning the sermon into a list of social ethics; focus the application on how the specific text 'expounds' the hearer's spiritual and psychological state today.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of three points (I, II, III), which separates the biblical text from the application. The text is used as a springboard for a 'practice' rather than the hearer being drawn into the movement of the text itself.
quotes: Second practice of discipleship: Watch your mouth!
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Abandon the 'three-point' structure in favor of a narrative or thematic movement where the text and the contemporary situation are interpreted simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon touches on 'misery' (greed, fear, social unrest) and 'gratitude' (contributing, joy), but it is too human-centered. It focuses on 'practices of discipleship' (man as subject) rather than God's act. Redemption is presented as a 'new world' we witness to, rather than a radical rescue from misery.
quotes: The temptation is always present in the church to drop in and drop out...
...the old world of greed and fear and threat has failed.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Shift the focus from 'human contribution' to God's sovereign act of redemption to avoid a moralistic tone.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: There is a mention of 'destruction' and 'perishing,' and the choice between the 'old world' and 'new world' is presented. However, the 'lostness' is primarily temporal/social (societal failure) rather than the ultimate seriousness Dekker describes.
quotes: The old world of greed and fear and threat has failed. There is no joy or security to be found in that way of life.
By your endurance you will gain your souls.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematize the possibility of being 'lost' more sharply—not just as a lack of 'joy' but as a failure to answer God's calling.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' and the one who gives 'mouth' and 'wisdom.' The sermon points to 'Easter truth.' However, Christ often functions as a 'model' (the one who 'acted out' the new world) rather than the ontological Savior (God-man) who is our only life.
quotes: This means to slant one’s life toward the newness of Jesus that he acted out before our very eyes.
The mouth that Jesus gives tells the truth...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Move beyond Jesus as a model for 'neighborliness' to Christ as the one in whom our life is hidden outside ourselves.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take roughly 11-12 minutes. This is significantly below Dekker's 20-minute minimum. The lack of length directly correlates with the lack of exegetical depth and the reliance on general 'counsel.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the breadth of the exposition to allow for deeper theological and psychological 'boring' into the text.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity, its thematic 'multi-text' approach, and its tendency toward moralism. It treats the Bible as a collection of 'useful counsel' for 'practices of discipleship' rather than a specific, current Word of God that must be uniquely expounded. The structure is too didactic (three points) and the duration is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth.'
strengths: Concrete contemporary references (oil spills, health care, immigration) avoid vague spiritualization.
Correct identification of the 2 Thessalonians context regarding work and the church body.
Clear attempt to link the 'misery' of the current zeitgeist (fear, greed) to the biblical text.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 11 minutes) prevents substantive theological exploration.
Thematic treatment of three texts violates the principle of the 'specific Bible passage.'
Moralistic tone: the sermon focuses heavily on what 'we' must do (contribute, watch our mouth) rather than what God has done.
Lack of 'interwoven' structure; it follows a traditional, somewhat boring, point-by-point application.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a 'speech about the gospel' and 'biblical ideas' (neighborliness, hope) rather than an exposition and application of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the necessary breadth and the specific 'NOWHERE else' quality required for true proclamation.
